Functions are useful because if you wish to run a block of code at a certain point again and donâ€™t feel like copying it into your code again, you can simply make a function which can be called again.

Functions can take parameters and also return edited inputs or global variables. It is all dependent on the scope of the variable.

Below we have an example of a function with and without parameters.

def sayHello():
  print("Hello!")

def addOne(x):
  return x + 1
  
number = 1
number = addOne(number)

sayHello()  # this calls our function, and the function executes

print(number) # this will print out 2
